comment_text: Am currently 7 months pregnant with my second and funny because am learning everyday.
(Relatively)new dad problems, Hank?

I gave birth to my 4th and last child in October 2019. They literally were able to detect the little bit of pot I smoked before finding out I was pregnant. I wasn't even 5 weeks when I found out and stopped smoking, and they could still detect it in the poop 9 months later. Which is kind of awesome bc obviously most drugs don't stay in your system long, and so if a pregnant woman were to go through their whole pregnancy using, just to stop when they go into labor.. it could leave their system by the time they give birth and doctors might not even know. But by testing that first poop they can see pretty much everything you take in while pregnant. I mean ngl I didn't live having to explain that, yes, I smoked a few joints 9 months ago.. but when you're a parent they need to come first like the more the doctors know, the better.
I'd bet all the "parents" mentioned in the research on alcohol and smoking influence were, in fact, mothers. Please do not destroy functional language to pander to political fads.

one more thing you missed but could be easily over looked is a baby's first poop is a great indicator that everything is connected properly and working like it should. our close friends had a baby and waited for it to poop but it never did, the doctors said to just give it a little time and it would come. well, the baby ended up vomiting it's first poop and the baby was immediately helicoptered to the nearest child's hospital to save it's life. it turns out the baby had an anus hole but the intestines were not connected to it in a rare condition called hirschsprung's disease. maybe you should do a video on that?

My oldest pooped sometime between my water breaking and birth because the fluid was clear when my water broke but not clear when she was born. It was a stressful labor and delivery, so not surprising. When her head came out, she spit up the dark fluid, then didn’t cry right away after being fully born. That was scary! They monitored her for 5 hours after birth but she was fine, thank goodness.

I work in a drug testing lab, and meconium is actually one of the specimens we test! And FAEEs is a compound we test for; in fact, I used to do the extraction work on samples being tested for FAEE. Let me tell you though, FAEE is just the tip of the iceberg. Our drug panels for Meconium go all the way up to a 14 panel, and we use Gas Chromatography/Mass Spectrometry (or GCMS for short) in our testing.

I was just talking about meconium at work!

My son was due at the end of September, but was still a no show by 10/15. The doctors scheduled me to induce labor on 10/24. Then at 3 am on 10/20 I woke up to a wet bed. My water had broke and there was blood everywhere. I continued to bleed, so I put on a sanitary pad to prevent bleed through. When I got to the hospital my pad had that first bowel movement in it. The doctor told me it was a sign of distress for the baby. I came in 1 centimeter dilated and, after 10 hours of labor, I never progressed. After the baby heart monitor showed further signs of distress, my son was finally born by C-section 13 hours later with a very cone shaped head. The xrays they took showed why. My pelvic bone was a 1/2 in. thicker than normal. His head was stuck in my pelvic bone, which was why  the labor didn't progress. After this history and, xrays of my 2nd pregnancy, it was determined that another C-section was the best course.

Because of a "rabbit trail" I took while researching another health question ... I found there are studies that found babies born by C-section have less gut bacteria than babies who are born vaginally ... which can most often lead to respiratory issues for those babies, such as asthma or allergies. Apparently, when babies are born vaginally, they get a "dose" of bacteria when their little faces pass through the vagina in birth. This seems to be the beginning of their gut microbiome which then is the beginning of their immune system and all sorts of other bodily functions that are connected to the gut. I've informally inquired of friends and family members as to how their children were born and I find this finding  is supported almost 100%.

Almost 40 years ago, my wife was working in a university research lab, attached to a teaching hospital.  The lab studied, among other things, meconium.  She was always on call during working hours to go fetch some that had became available in the nearby neonatal ward.  And yes, if there are signs of meconium in the amniotic fluid when the mother's water breaks, doctors are on alert for possible issues with the baby.
